A ternary nanocomposite comprising phosphotungstic acid (PW12), polyethyleneimine (PEI), and graphene oxide (GO), i.e., PW12-PEI/GO, was developed as a precursor to obtain the W2C/N-rGO catalyst upon in-situ carbonization. W2C/N-rGO was applied in the deep oxidative desulfurization (ODS) of liquid fuel, and exhibited extraordinary performance due to the ultrafine W2C nanoparticles (～3–5 nm) evenly dispersed on N-rGO and the electron-donating effect of N-rGO on W2C. 4000 ppm of DBT in model oil could be completely removed within only 10 min with a remarkably high turnover frequency (168 h−1) and the lower activation energy (30.9 kJ·mol−1). Radical experiments and density functional theory calculations indicate that the ODS reaction proceeds mainly via a HO• radical mechanism. Moreover, W2C/N-rGO could be recycled for 6 successive cycles with no obvious loss of performance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords In-situ carbonization N-doped graphene Phosphotungstic acid Ultrafine W2C nanoparticles Oxidative desulfurization 1 Introduction Due to the increasing demand for energy, especially fuel, but the decreasing reserves, the low-quality fossil fuels containing more impurities (e.g., S, N, and so on) have to be used inevitably, which would lead to the augmented emission of SOx and NOx gases. Especially, SOx generated from combusting the sulfur-containing fuel has been proved to be one of the most serious pollutants to the environment and human health, such as corrosion of buildings and soil eutrophication, the development of acid rain, the corrosion of automobile tail gas treatment devices, and the increase in respiratory disease and cancer [1–4]. Given these reasons, the increasingly stringent sulfur level of liquid fuels has been imposed by various environmental regulatory agencies across the globe, for example, 10 ppm and 60 ppb for transport fuel and fuel cells, respectively [5,6], and many countries and regions have adopted it. However, these stringent conditions on sulfur level would continue to be tightened in the future. Therefore, the highly efficient desulfurization from the fuel feedstocks has become a research hotspot. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) has been conventionally applied for desulfurization of liquid fuels, yet it suffers to the severe operating conditions, such as, high temperature (T > 350 ℃), high pressures (30–100 bar) and a lot of hydrogen, and fails to efficiently remove the aromatic sulfur compounds, such as benzothiophene (BT), dibenzothiophene (DBT), 4,6- dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) and its derivatives [7,8]. Therefore, it is essential to develop alternative or supplementary energy-efficient and cost-effective technologies for desulfurization to meet the fuel specification [9,10]. So far, biological desulphurization (BDS) [11], adsorption desulfurization (ADS) [12], extraction desulfurization (EDS) [13], oxidation desulfurization (ODS) [14–16], and photocatalytic oxidation desulfurization [17,18] have been developed to remove the refractory thiophenics from fuels. Among all these methods, ODS as a promising method has received increasing attention from the researchers owing to its eco-sustainability, mild operation condition, very high efficiency, and low cost. The refractory sulfur compounds are oxidized to the corresponding sulfones and/or sulfoxides with strong polarity, and then facilely separated and recycled by extraction, adsorption or distillation, respectively, which are all low cost. Also, these sulfones are widely used in organic solar cells, organic field effect transistors, chemical or pharmaceutical intermediates, and so on. However, a highly reactive catalyst has always been necessary to ensure the ODS efficiency. Although various metal species (Mo, W, Ti, Ni, V, Co, Cr, Mn, or Fe) as catalysts have been studied extensively [19–23] to activate oxygen species (from oxidants) for ODS, it is still challenging to develop a cost-effective, highly active catalyst with desirable consecutive recycling for the prospective commercialization of ODS technology. Recently, the transition-metal carbides (W2C, WC, Mo2C, Ni3C, V8C7, etc.) [24], especially tungsten carbides (W2C and WC), have increasingly attracted the attention of scientists on account of their earth-abundance, inexpensive cost, the platinum-like [25] and peroxidase-like [26] performance in surface catalysis, excellent physical property and chemical stability, and so on, which have been widely applied in a range of important reactions, such as, hydrogenolysis, isomerization reaction, fuel cell, hydrogen evolution, catalytic oxidation, and biology [27,28]. And they have been conventionally prepared using high-temperature (＞700℃) reduction of metal precursors with gaseous carbon precursors (such as CH4, C2H6 or CO). According to the literatures and theoretical calculations, W2C possesses higher catalytic efficiency than WC [29]. However, the ODS activity of tungsten carbide, especially W2C, has rarely been reported as far as we know. Additionally, any catalytic material is useless without high surface area or good dispersion, so the supported W2C is very attractive, especially for catalysis [30–32]. The commonly used catalyst carrier materials include zeolite molecular sieve [33], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [34], mesoporous silica [35], carbon nanotubes [36], graphene oxide [37], etc. Among them, 2D graphene oxide (2D GO) not only possesses unique thermal, mechanical and electroconductivity properties as well as high specific surface area, but also contains oxygen-containing functional groups, such as carboxyl, hydroxyl, carbonyl and epoxy groups, which is beneficial to its chemical modification [38]. Recently, the reported [39] has shown that the well-dispersed W2C anchored onto N/P-codoped reduced graphene oxide composite (W2C@N/P-rGO) was prepared from pyrolysis of PTA/PPy/2D GO composites composed of phosphotungstic acid (PTA), polypyrrole (PPy) and 2D GO, and presented significantly improved electrochemical performance and good cycling stability. Based on our first recent discovery that W2C can be used as an effective catalyst for ODS of fuel oils [40], in this work, we have devised and controllably prepared the well-dispersed ultrafine W2C nanoparticles supported on the reduced graphene oxide (W2C/N-rGO, hereafter) via a high temperature carbonization method of a well-organized precursor in which PTA is used as W sources, and polyethyleneimine-modified GO (PEI/GO) as C source, N source and carrier. After detailed characterization, the as-synthesized product was applied in the ODS of model and real fuels, respectively. The optimized catalyst (W2C/N-rGO) exhibited outstanding ODS performances of various thiophenics (thiophene, benzothiophene, dibenzothiophene, etc.), with the maximum kinetic constant, remarkably high turnover frequency (TOF), lower activation energy, and facile reusability. The ODS mechanism of W2C/N-rGO was revealed via the combination of the radical scavenging experiments and theoretical calculations. In this regard, the newly prepared W2C/N-rGO can be recommended as a potential catalyst for ODS of liquid fuels. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and reagents All the chemicals and reagents in this study (see Section 1 of Supporting Information (SI) for details) were of analytical grade, and purchased from commercial venders, and used without any further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of the catalyst Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared by a modified Hummers method as described in the previous report [41], followed by covalent linking of polyethyleneimine (PEI) onto GO via the amidation reaction between amine group of PEI and carboxylic groups of GO with N-(3-Dimethylaminopropyl)-N′-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC·HCl) as activation agent to obtain the PEI-modified GO (PEI/GO) [42] (see Section 2 of Supporting Information (SI) for more details). 0.2 g of PEI/GO was added into 20 mL of deionized water, and its pH value was adjusted to be 4, so as to form solution A; and 0.6 g of PW12 was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water, forming solution B. Then the solution B was added dropwise into solution A, and stirred at room temperature for 12 h. Subsequently, the solid product was collected by centrifugation, repeatedly washed by deionized water, and freeze-dried for two days, obtaining PW12-PEI/GO precursor. After that, the final product was obtained after calcinating the precursor powders in a tube furnace in the temperature range of 300–1000 ℃ (ramped at a rate of 5 ℃ min−1) for 2 h under N2 atmosphere. The calcinated products were named as PW12/N-GO, WO3/N-rGO, W2C-W-W2N/N-rGO, and W2C/N-rGO depending on the phases of W species (PW12, WO3, W2C-W-W2N, and W2C were obtained at around 300–500, 700, 800, and 1000 ℃, respectively, as shown in Section 3) within them. The schematic illustration of the preparation process of W2C/N-rGO derived from calcining PW12-PEI/GO at 1000 ℃ is shown in Fig. 1. 2.3 Characterizations Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were performed on a L1600300 Spectrum Two LITa infrared spectrometer (UK) using the KBr pellet approach. Ultraviolet-Visible spectra of the samples were recorded on a 2802 UV/Vis instrument (Youniko, Shanghai). Scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) was determined with a Hitachi S4800 / FEI NANOSEM 450 microscope (USA). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analytical data were acquired on EDAX Apollo XT spectrometer (USA). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images were carried out using a Talos F200S instrument (USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was obtained on a Thermo Fisher Scientific Escalab 250Xi X-ray photoelectron Spectrometer (American) using Al Ka radiation and the C1s peak at 284.8 eV as internal standard. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected with Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer (Germany) using a Cu Kα source to determine the chemical composition and crystalline structural properties of the samples. Synchronous thermal analyser (TG) was carried out by a NETZSCH STA 449 F3 analyzer (Germany). The activate radicals were determined by EPR (MiniSpcope MS 5000, Magnettech, Germany) with 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrrolidine-N-oxide (DMPO) as electron capturing reagent. Tungsten content was tested by inductively-coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110, USA). High performance liquid chromatograph (HPLC, LC98-I, Beijing Wenfen Analysis Instrument Technology Development Co., Ltd) and the high resolution mass spectrometer (HRMS) were used to confirm the ODS reaction product. 2.4 ODS of model fuels Model fuel solutions (500–6000 ppm S) were prepared by dissolving BT, Th, 4,6-DMDBT and DBT in n-octane, respectively. The ODS experiments were carried out under the atmospheric pressure in a reaction vessel equipped with a condenser pipe and mechanical agitation. In a typical procedure, 30 mg of the prepared catalyst was added into the biphasic system composed of 20 mL of model fuel and 20 mL of acetonitrile (ACN), followed by stirring the system for a few minutes to perform the initial extraction. After that, a certain amount of 30 % H2O2 solution were added into the system, and it was heated up to a certain value, and finally the ODS reaction occurred at this temperature for a certain time. During ODS reaction, 100 μL of oil solution was taken from the upper n-octane phase at a given time interval and diluted with 4 mL of n-octane for the detection of the residual sulfur concentration by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (see Section 3 of Supporting Information (SI) for more details). The oxidation products in ACN phase were characterized by HRMS analysis. After the ODS reaction, the catalyst was filtered and collected, then washed with ethanol and ACN and dried at 60 ℃ overnight for repeated use. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. S1 shows the FT-IR spectra of PW12, PEI/GO, PW12-PEI/GO and GO. In the FT-IR spectrum of GO, the peaks at 1734 cm−1, 1624 cm−1 and 1055 cm−1 are attributed to the CO, CC and epoxy groups stretching vibration, respectively. After bonding with PEI, the peak at 1734 cm−1 vanishes, and several new characteristic peaks appear at 2849 and 2930 cm−1 (-CH2 symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration), 1456 cm−1 (C-N stretching vibration), indicating the successful covalent attachment of PEI onto GO [43]. In the spectrum of PW12, the characteristic peaks at 1079, 982, 886, and 800 cm−1 are assigned to P-Oa, WOd, W-Ob-W and W-Oc-W, respectively. After the formation of PW12-PEI/GO composite, in addition to the characteristic peaks of PEI/GO, the peaks of PW12 also appear at 1091, 950, and 796 cm−1, and shift to different degrees relative to that of the pure PW12. Moreover, the peak at 886 cm−1 almost disappears. All of these changes are attributed to the electrostatic interaction between PW12 and PEI/GO. The FT-IR spectra of calcined samples of PW12-PEI/GO at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 2A. As depicted in Fig. 2A, in the spectra of calcined samples at 300 and 500 ℃, all the typical absorption peaks of PW12 of PW12-PEI/GO could still be found, and the peak shapes and positions of them are closer to that of the pure PW12. However, the characteristic peaks of PEI/GO in PW12-PEI/GO change greatly, and the peaks at 1624 and 1456 cm−1 decrease greatly, manifesting that its structure is destroyed. While, in the TG curve of PW12-PEI/GO (Fig. S2), it exhibits obvious weight loss in 300–500 ℃ due to the pyrolysis of PEI molecules covalently bonded on GO [44], which confirms again that the structure of PEI/GO in PW12-PEI/GO is destroyed to varying degrees at 300 and 500 ℃. After calcination at 700 ℃, not only the peaks of PEI/GO in PW12-PEI/GO at 1624 and 1456 cm−1 decrease further, but also the characteristic peaks of PW12 at 1075 and 814 cm−1 decrease and those at 973 and 893 cm−1 almost disappear, which is similar to that of the calcined product of the pure PW12 at 1000 ℃ (Fig. S3A). And the calcined product of pure PW12 at 1000 ℃ is certified to be WO3 by the XRD pattern (Fig. S3B). With the increasing calcination temperature up to 800–1000 ℃, the FT-IR spectra of the calcined samples from PW12-PEI/GO are similar to that of the carbonization product from PEI/GO (Fig. S3C), and the characteristic peaks of PW12 almost completely disappear, and no peaks of self-decomposition products of PW12 appear, speculating that the decomposition products of PW12 and the carbonization product from PEI/GO could interact with each other during calcination to form new species, which will be confirmed by the following XRD patterns. In the UV-Vis absorption spectra of PW12, PW12-PEI/GO and its calcined samples at different temperatures (Fig. S4), it is found that with the increasing calcination temperatures from 300 to 1000 ℃, the intensities of absorption peaks at 194 nm and 265 nm, attributed to the charge transfer from the terminal oxygen to tungsten (Od→W) and bridge-oxygen to tungsten (Ob / Oc→W) [45], respectively, gradually weaken, and the absorption peak at 265 nm becomes wider, revealing that PW12 is structurally damaged to varying degrees, which is consistent with the above result of FT-IR spectra. The crystalline structures of PW12-PEI/GO and its calcined samples at different temperatures were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 2B). As can be seen in Fig. 2B, the XRD patterns of the calcined samples from PW12-PEI/GO at 300–500 ℃ are similar to that of the precursor PW12-PEI/GO, indicating the essentially unchanged structure. When the calcination temperature elevates to 700 ℃, two new peaks at 23.8° and 33.8° are observed, corresponding to the WO3 phase, illustrating that PW12 in PW12-PEI/GO decomposes into WO3. Besides, the diffraction peak of GO at 8.4° disappears due to its reduction at 700 ℃. In XRD pattern of the calcined sample at 800 ℃, not only the diffraction peaks of WO3 phase disappears, but also some other diffraction peaks are found, for example, the peaks located at 34.7, 38.1, 39.7, 52.5, 61.9 and 69.9° are attributed to W2C, those at 37.5 and 43.8° are indexed to W2N; those at 40.1, 58.1, 73.0 and 86.9° correspond to the metallic W. However, with the further increasing calcination temperature up to 1000 ℃, the main diffraction peaks at 34.7, 38.1, 39.7, 52.5, 61.9, 69.9, 75.2 and 85.3° are detected and assigned to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (112) and (202) crystal planes of hexagonal W2C, respectively, matching well with W2C according to PDF#35–0776, but the peak at 48.1° belongs to WO3 resulting from the inevitable surface oxidation of W2C nanoparticles exposed to air, which is consistent with the XPS results. Meanwhile, almost all the other peaks have disappeared, indicating the high purity. According to the above results, it can be inferred that as the calcination temperature increases, the tungsten species could undergo the following process: PW12→WO3→WO2→W2C-W-W2N→W2C. Finally, W2C/N-rGO is obtained by calcining PW12-PEI/GO at 1000 ℃. SEM images of PW12-PEI/GO and W2C/N-rGO are shown in Fig. 3(A-D). SEM images of PW12-PEI/GO as displayed in Fig. 3A and B show that many nanoparticles (i.e. PW12-containing PEI) are distributed on GO. After calcination at 1000 ℃, it is noted in the SEM images of W2C/N-rGO (Fig. 3C and D) that those nanoparticles distributed on GO disappear, and the graphene surface is smooth again. Combined with the TEM images of W2C/N-rGO (Fig. 3E and F), it can be seen that the ultrafine W2C nanoparticles (3–5 nm) (Fig. 3F, the inset spectra) are homogeneously distributed on graphene sheets. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image (Fig. 3G) indicates that the d spacing of W2C are 0.236 and 0.228 nm, ascribed to the (002) and (101) plane of W2C [46]. EDX spectrum (Fig. 3H) manifests that the W2C/N-rGO composite was composed of N, O, P, C and W elements, but there's very little doping of P and N which originate from PW12 and PEI, respectively. The O element results from the inevitable oxygen absorption from air and a little surface oxidation of tungsten carbide. Furthermore, the elemental mapping images of W2C/N-rGO in Fig. 3a-e show that C, N, O, P and W elements are evenly dispersed in it. To gain insight on the chemical environment and bonding configuration of W2C in W2C/N-rGO, XPS characterizations were performed on the W2C/N-rGO. The survey spectrum of W2C/N-rGO in Fig. S5A illustrates that C, N, P, O and W elements present in W2C/N-rGO, which is consistent with the EDX result. The C 1s XPS result ( Fig. 4A) can be split into four peaks. The sharp peak at 284.8 eV is attributed to CC/C-C bond in rGO [47]. The peaks 285.5 eV, 286.9 eV and 289.9 eV can be to C-P/C-N, C-O and O-CO, respectively [39,48], which indicated the partial oxidation of the graphene surface. The peak at 284.3 eV is assigned to C-W [32]. The W 4f XPS spectrum (Fig. 4B) can be deconvoluted into three peaks of W-P, W-C and W-O with binding energies of 32.8, 32.0 eV/34.3 eV, and 36.2 eV/38.3 eV, respectively [48]. Among them, the W-O bond results from the inevitable surface oxidation of W2C nanoparticles due to its exposure to air. The N 1s XPS spectrum exhibits three types of nitrogen environments, which can be attributed to pyridinic-N (399.0 eV), pyrrolic-N (400.3 eV), and graphitic-N (401.5 eV) [49], and the high ratio of graphitic-N manifests the highly N-doped rGO. The P 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. S5B) shows three peaks, ascribing to the P-C, P-O and P-W bonds with binding energies of 133.8, 135.0 and 129.5 eV, respectively [48]. These results indicate that N and P were co-doped in graphene. For O1s spectrum (Fig. S5C), the peaks at 531.2 eV, 532.0 and 533.6 eV correspond to C=O, C-O-C and O-H, respectively, and the peak at 530.6 eV is ascribed to W-O leaded by the samples contacted with air [47]. 3.2 Catalytic oxidation performances Based on the ODS reaction results of different catalytic systems included in the Fig. S6, H2O2 and W2C/N-rGO are both necessary for the effective ODS, while the ODS efficiencies of DBT over pyrolyzed products WO3 (being verified by the FT-IR spectrum and XRD pattern in Fig. S3A, B) or N-rGO from pure PW12 or PEI/GO are very low in the presence of H2O2. Besides, to verify the actual oxidation of DBT over W2C/N-rGO, the adsorption experiment of DBT over it was also carried out in the absence of H2O2, and the results in Fig. S7 indicate that although DBT could be slightly removed by adsorption through π-π and S-π interactions, and the acid-base interactions between it and W2C/N-rGO [50,51], it was much lower than that via oxidation. What’s more, as shown in Fig. S8B, all of DBT extracted by acetonitrile could be immediately oxidized into the sole dibenzothiophene sulfone (DBTO2) under a certain condition (m (W2C/N-rGO) = 0.03 g, n(H2O2) / n(S) = 2, T = 70 ℃), which has been further confirmed via the APCI-HRMS spectra of the acetonitrile phase in Fig. S9, indicating high efficiency and selectivity of the W2C/N-rGO catalyst. Moreover, in the presence of H2O2, the ODS performances of DBT over the calcined samples from PW12-PEI/GO composite at different temperatures were investigated. As shown in Fig. 5A, the removal of DBT over the different samples follow the order: W2C/N-rGO (1000 ℃) ＞W2C-W-W2N/N-rGO (800 ℃) > WO3/N-rGO (700 ℃) ＞ PW12/N-GO (500 ℃) > PW12/N-GO (300 ℃) ＞PW12-PEI/GO, which is mainly assigned to the diverse structures of them. In general, based on the carrier N-rGO, the newly developed pure-phase W2C catalyst affords much better ODS performance than W2C-W-W2N, WO3 and the conventional polyoxometallate (PW12) catalysts. The removal rate of DBT over W2C/N-rGO is 97.7 %, 99.4 % and 100 % only within 2, 7 and 10 min, respectively, and 10 min is almost the shortest time reported for the complete removal of DBT with high sulfur content (＞1000 ppm) [2,52–60], while the complete removal time (15 min) of DBT over W2C-W-W2N/N-rGO is next to that over W2C/N-rGO. In view of the minimum time for the completed removal of DBT, W2C/N-rGO is selected as the optimum catalyst. As shown in Fig. S10, although W2C/N-rGO has a smaller specific surface area compared to rGO, it possesses the mesoporous structure ranged from 2 to 30 nm, and could facilitate the diffusion of reactants and products during ODS reaction, so as to benefit the ODS performance. Moreover, W2C/N-rGO in this study exhibits a far better ODS performance than the bulk W2C in our previous work [40], due to the highly exposed active sites from the ultrafine and well dispersed W2C nanoparticles on N-rGO. In addition, as one of the most important parameters for evaluating the catalyst activity, TOF of W2C/N-rGO was calculated to be 168.0 h−1 using W atom as the active site (see the formula (3) in SI for more detail), which is higher than most of the references [2,52–55,57,58,61]. W2C/N-rGO is employed to catalyze the removal of DBT with different S contents in order to further investigate its catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 5B, the removal of DBT by W2C/N-rGO can be complete within 2, 5, 7, 10 and 30 min at S contents of 500, 1000, 3000, 4000 and 5000 ppm, respectively, and it can still be up to 99.5 % within 40 min even at the higher S content of 6000 ppm, indicating that the W2C/N-rGO catalyst can serve on an effective catalyst for the ODS reaction of fuel oil over a wide range of S content. Also, the effects of the loading amount of W atoms in W2C/N-rGO, n(H2O2) / n(S) molar ratio, and catalyst (W2C/N-rGO) dosage on the DBT removal were explored to determine the optimum condition of the ODS. As shown in Fig. S11, considering the best performance of W2C/N-rGO, the loading amount of W atom, catalyst dosage and n(H2O2) / n(S) molar ratio were optimized as 54.70 %, 0.03 g, and 2 mol⋅mol−1 (equal to the theoretical value of 2), respectively. In addition, the temperature has a great influence on the ODS reaction over W2C/N-rGO catalyst, as illustrated in Fig. 6A. In view of the too fast desulfurization rate over W2C/N-rGO with larger dosage 0.03 g, 0.01 g of W2C/N-rGO is used to evaluate the ODS reaction kinetics of DBT by it and calculate the apparent activation energy (E a ) (see Section 4 of SI for more detail), as shown in Fig. 6B. It can be concluded that rising temperature is favorable for ODS reaction, and all of these ODS reactions of DBT follow pseudo-first-order kinetics model with high correlation coefficients (R2＞0.99). Besides, based on the Arrhenius plot depicted in Fig. 6C, the apparent activation energy (E a ) for the ODS reaction of DBT was calculated to be 30.9 kJ⋅mol−1. In view of the short time for complete sulfur removal, high TOF, as well as the low E a value ( Table 1), W2C/N-rGO can be comprehensively considered an extraordinary ODS catalyst. 3.3 Mechanism for the oxidation of dibenzothiophene over W2C/N-rGO Usually, the oxidation reaction of thiophene takes place through a nucleophilic attack of its S atom to active oxygen species generated from oxidizing agents (such as H2O2), resulting in the increasing ODS efficiency with the electron density on the S atom [53,63]. In the present study, the desulfurization rate of the selected sulfides ( Fig. 7A) (excluding 4,6-DMDBT) decreased in order: DBT > BT > Th, which followed the above hypothesis based on the order of electron density on the S atom (5.758, 5.739 and 5.696 for DBT, BT and Th [64], respectively). However, despite having the highest electron density on the S atom of 4,6-DMDBT (5.760), it showed the lower reaction rate, which might be due to the steric hindrance of the bulky methyl groups on the benzene ring of 4,6-DMDBT, as shown in the reports [52]. To gain more insight into the ODS mechanism of W2C/N-rGO with H2O2 as oxidizing agents, radical scavenging experiments were performed with dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), AgNO3, and p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) as quenchers for hydroxide radical (HO•), electron (e-), and superoxide anion radical (O2•-), respectively. As shown in Fig. 7B, compared to the blank scavenger-free experiment, the DBT removal were not noticeably reduced even in the presence of 1,4-benzoquinone (BQ) or AgNO3, implying no formation of O2•- or e- in the ODS process. It is worth mentioning that the addition of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as HO• radical scavenger makes the removal rate of DBT decreased from 100 % to 73.3 % at 10 min, indicating HO• (as confirmed by EPR experiment (Fig. S12) [65]) plays a certain role for the DBT oxidation. DFT calculations were carried out to further probe the interaction between 2D-W2C surface and N-doped graphene, and then to explain the ODS reaction pathway of DBT compound by elucidating the electronic structure and Gibbs free energies of the reaction. So we built W2C/N-doped graphene interface (Fig. 7C) and the H2O2 and DBT adsorption on it. For more computational details, please see the Section 5 of SI. After geometry optimization of the 2D-W2C/N-doped grapheme interface, the adhesion energy between these two facets is about − 7.62 eV and the interface lattice mismatch is below 5 %, indicating a stable and intimate interaction at the interface. In addition, for the enhanced catalytic activity in our experiment, the interfacial charge transfer efficiency in the W2C/N-doped graphene was further evaluated by the charge density difference analysis (Fig. 7D). It can be seen that the charge redistribution occurs across the interfacial region of W2C/N-doped graphene, and the electrons can transfer from the N-doped garphene to the 2D-W2C surface through the interface, resulting in the distribution of most of charges at the 2D-W2C side. The electron-donating N-rGO can increase the dispersion of W2C and reduce its leaching via the strong interfacial electrostatic interaction caused by the electron transfer from N-rGO to W2C, so as to improve the catalytic activity [61]. Moreover, the enhanced electronegativity of W2C can still benefit the decomposition of H2O2 into HO• radicals on it through electron transfer like peroxidase [26,28,60]. Further, HO• (oxidation-reduction potential E0 = 1.8–2.7 V) has strong non-selective catalytic activity in most organic pollutants oxidation, and can react very fast with most organics in solution [66]. According to the current experimental results that HO• is also responsible for the DBT oxidation, so in order to determine the type of sulfur oxidation products by HO•, the reaction mechanism of the adsorbed DBT and HO• were calculated with G09 software, using the M06–2X functional [67] and 6–31 + +g(d, p) basis set, as shown in Fig. 6E, revealing the two steps of DBT oxidation pathway, i.e. the first step (O-DBT) and second step oxidation (O2-DBT) with the elementary reaction energy barriers of 3.57 kJ / mol and 11.34 kJ / mol, respectively. And the formation of intermediate product DBTO and final oxidation product DBTO2 were confirmed by HPLC chromatograms of acetonitrile (ACN) phase for the ODS of DBT model oil over W2C/N-rGO with lower dosage, as depicted in Fig. S13. In addition, Fig. S14 still shows that the DBT removal rate in the coexistence of H2O2 and DMSO is larger than that in the absence of H2O2 and DMSO, due to the promoted extraction of acetonitrile phase towards DBT by DMSO. As depicted in Fig. S15, the removed DBT in n-octane phase under the coexistence of H2O2 and DMSO, has been extracted into acetonitrile phase without any oxidation products. However, the slightly larger DBT removal rate in the coexistence of H2O2 and DMSO than that in only DMSO would be attributed to the few surface reactive oxygen (O*) species formed over W2C/N-rGO, which is similar to our previous research work [40]. Because of the small amount of oxidation products, the corresponding peak cannot be observed in HPLC chromatograms of acetonitrile phase (Fig. S15B). According to all of the above experiments and DFT results, a possible ODS mechanism of DBT over W2C/N-rGO was proposed ( Fig. 8). First, the DBT molecule in model oil is transferred into acetonitrile phase due to the extraction of DBT by acetonitrile and its adsorption by W2C/N-rGO, and then oxidized immediately into DBTO2 by H2O2 in the presence of the W2C/N-rGO catalyst in acetonitrile phase (Fig. S8). The extraction and oxidation process alternately until DBT is completely removed from the oil phase. Furthermore, three stages are contained during the oxidation of DBT in acetonitrile phase: 1) generation of HO• radicals from the decomposition of H2O2 by the highly active W2C ultrafine nanoparticles (3–5 nm) homogeneously distributed on N-rGO; 2) oxidation of DBT into DBTO by HO• radicals; 3) the further oxidation of DBTO into DBTO2 by HO• radicals. It is the synergistic effect of the oxidation by HO• radicals and extraction the that leads to the excellent ODS performance of DBT by W2C/N-rGO. The above oxidation mechanism is obviously different from the general oxidation of DBT by H2O2 over W-based catalysts that involves the formation of active pseudo-cyclic peroxo-metal species in the previous reports [58,68,69]. 3.4 Recyclability of W2C/N-rGO A leaching test was carried out to verify the heterogeneity of the W2C/N-rGO catalyst. It can be seen in the Fig. 9A that after W2C/N-rGO is separated at 2 min reaction time, the oxidation removal of DBT is almost completely inhibited, indicating that no W2C leaching has occurred, i.e. W2C/N-rGO has a good stability, which is due to the strong interfacial electrostatic interaction caused by the electron transfer from N-rGO to W2C. Moreover, the recyclability of W2C/N-rGO in DBT oxidation was investigated after regeneration by filtration, washing with ethanol and acetonitrile. As shown in Fig. 9B, W2C/N-rGO could be reused without significant loss of reactivity after 6 successive recycles. The almost identical XRD patterns (Fig. 9C) of fresh and recovered W2C/N-rGO confirm again the excellent reusability of the catalyst. 4 Conclusions In short, a novel W2C/N-rGO catalyst for the ODS reaction of fuel oil was successfully developed by in-situ carbonization using the PW12-PEI/GO composite as the precursor. With H2O2 as oxidant, 4000 ppm of DBT in model oil could be 100 % removed by W2C/N-rGO catalyst within 10 min, showing the outstanding ODS performance of DBT compared with other catalysts. The ODS reaction mechanism could be explained via the synergistic effect of the extraction and the oxidation by HO• radicals generated from the decomposition of H2O2 over W2C/N-rGO. Moreover, the W2C/N-rGO catalyst showed very good regeneration and reusability in the ODS of model oil for up to the sixth runs. The remarkable ODS activity and reusability of W2C/N-rGO depended mainly on the ultrafine particle size of W2C, and the electron-donating effect of N-rGO on W2C, which could not only promote the dispersion of W2C and reduce the leaching of it by enhancing the interfacial electrostatic interaction, but also improve the decomposition of H2O2 to HO• via the formation of the electron-rich active W species (i.e. W2C) caused by the electron transfer from N-rGO to W2C. This work provided a novel and high-efficiency ODS catalyst, which exhibited great potential for further application. coredata.dc:description: A ternary nanocomposite comprising phosphotungstic acid (PW12), polyethyleneimine (PEI), and graphene oxide (GO), i.e., PW12-PEI/GO, was developed as a precursor to obtain the W2C/N-rGO catalyst upon in-situ carbonization. W2C/N-rGO was applied in the deep oxidative desulfurization (ODS) of liquid fuel, and exhibited extraordinary performance due to the ultrafine W2C nanoparticles (～3–5 nm) evenly dispersed on N-rGO and the electron-donating effect of N-rGO on W2C. 4000 ppm of DBT in model oil could be completely removed within only 10 min with a remarkably high turnover frequency (168 h−1) and the lower activation energy (30.9 kJ·mol−1). Radical experiments and density functional theory calculations indicate that the ODS reaction proceeds mainly via a HO• radical mechanism. Moreover, W2C/N-rGO could be recycled for 6 successive cycles with no obvious loss of performance.
coredata.dc:title: Ultrafine W2C well-dispersed on N-doped graphene: Extraordinary catalyst for ultrafast oxidative desulfurization of high sulfur liquid fuels
